He thinks he's smarter than everyone else in the universe.
And he thinks he's more complex than everyone else in the universe.
And that he can't be wrong.
I beg to differ.

489864.body: This is the BEST resource ever for wine lovers! It has a two-way index: you can search on a food to figure out what wine to drink with it, or you can search on wines to figure out what food to make with it. Unbelievably helpful. My husband calls it "The Bible." We refer to it at LEAST once a week...

489866.body: After working in a domestic violence shelter, this book hits a little too close to home. The made for t.v. movie changed the ending (a mistake) and the book always haunts me for a couple days after reading it.

489876.body: I really didn't like this one all that much. I don't really see why it earned the Newbury Award. I didn't identify with the main character and her problems, not did I find the action of the story all that interesting.

489889.body: I read this as an adult because I learned it was a frequently challenged book. I thought it was alright, but I didn't think it should be banned. It is really a story about bullying and is only banned / challenged because the adults aren't portrayed well.

489890.body: This is a fun, easy, comical read. If you are looking for something similar to "A Girls Guide to Hunting and Fishing" and smarter than "Bridget Jones", Jennifer Weiner's books are always a good choice!

489891.body: A realistic love story. I read this as an adult because it was frequently challenged. I don't think I will ever forget how in my second year of teaching a student borrowed this book. She loved it; she loved it so much that she gave it right to her friend to read before returning it to me. This is...

489898.body: I had liked a lot of Judy Blume's other books, so I read this one a while later. I didn't like it as much as her books targeted for slightly younger girls, but it was still a good story. I think it might have affected me more if I had dealt with loss before I read it.

489900.body: This is the sequel to Just as Long as We're Together. I read it when I was a little older than when I read the first one. I didn't like it anywhere near as much. This one follows the character of Rachel and doesn't deal with the friend issues as much as family.

489905.body: This one is a little hazy. I remember that is had to do some with racism as the main character is white and she spends time with her new neighbors who are black. I'm sure there was more to it than that, but I'm not very clear on it.

489917.body: Steverino's mind was a marvel. Great insights into the inconsistensies in the Bible.

489919.body: The letter exchange between Dalton Trumbo and Allen is worth the price of the book.

489925.body: This book is my spiritual guide to life. I re-read it in full every year and browse through it nearly monthly.

489930.body: A quick read. It was an engaging elaboration on the nature of Elminster's relationships to his beloved goddess and his cherished Realms.

489942.body: An interesting story arc, great characters, and excellent spell descriptions by one of the creators of the Forgotten Realms. If you enjoy D&D, you'll love this book.

489957.body: What a great wake-up call to the realities of the justice system. This was an absolute page-turner.

489970.body:
A comprehensive manual to approaching the manifestation of anything conceivable! Replete with quotes to inspire and examples to entertain. Hold on to your analogies -- this one's a keeper.

489971.body: Great, fun, reads that allowed me to learn something about African cultures. Highly recommend.

489974.body: An awesome book about love and generosity. I am fairly certain this was read aloud to me in grade school by a teacher or the librarian. I reread it as an adult more than once and gave it to my father one year for Christmas.

489975.body: Amazing, beautiful and haunting. Not to mention disturbing. Makes me feel like I need to keep a vigil around my son at all times so he doesn't get snatched.

489979.body: Lots of fun for a basketball junkie.

489981.body: Great insight into mid-20th century South. Great storyline.

489983.body: Loved the idea, as I'm a bit of a grammar nerd. But it didn't offer anything new and harped on the same things over and over again.

489986.body: I am a huge fan of Wallace Stegner, and this is my favorite book of his...in fact, it's my favorite book of all time. I just find the story of the friendship of these two couples so engrossing, so real, so thought-provoking. I ENVY any of you reading this for the first time.

489998.body: Even though this was written by her grand-nephew, the voice of Julia Child comes through loud and clear. It is just a charming account of a woman who found her path later in life. Thoroughly enjoyable...another book I couldn't put down. I think I read the entire thing on a flight to France.

490007.body: I reread this about every five years and I wish I could read it more often than that. Anne (with an E) is one of my favorite literary characters.

490010.body:
This book inspired everyone on my book group to head to Istanbul. Great accounts from women living and traveling through the country as foreigners.

Re-read this 12/10 while in Istanbul. FANTASTIC as a way of getting some more insight into the city and country.

490017.body: I ADORE the books by this couple. The chapters offer a wonderfully accessilble way to learn about all wine varietals. The personal stories of the couple take away the dryness of many other wine books - it offered me a much better way to get a grounding in new types of wine.

490031.body: I don't know when I've read a book that knocked the wind out of me as much as this one did. A classic--one of my all-time favorites. His other books are either enjoyable or tedious; it may be a once-in-a-lifetime achievement. I hope not.
